Posts.Title: Fibrocystic changes post-menopause or time for second opinion? Kristee fenella

Posts.Content: Kristee wrote: Well, this has been a confusing journey so far.  I had a hysterectomy and both ovaries removed since 2008 and have been on oral estrogen ever since without any major problems.  Three months ago, I noticed an area in the upper outer quadrant of my right breast that felt different than everywhere else and was painful sometimes.  No specific lump.  It became increasingly painful, and my GP felt some obvious thickening.  Mammo and ultrasound were negative. Fast forward to yesterday when I saw a surgeon who does a lot of breast surgery.  He told me I had fibrocystic changes which were causing the pain.  When I asked him why the right side now seemed asymmetrical with extra creases near the armpit where the thickening is (for lack of a better description), he said it fell within the 10-15% range of normal variance.  Then he said the symptoms should resolve when I enter menopause at age 50 (I'm 41 now).  I reminded him I'm post-menopausal already, to which he said it must be hormonal and that was not his department.  Recent hormone blood tests were ok. I've never had any problems with my breasts prior to this and always thought post-menopausal changes were treated as more suspicious until proven otherwise.  Am I mistaken?  Dr specifically said "no surgery needed" due to low risk of cancer.  Should I ask for a second opinion referral (which has to come from GP here in Ontario)?  I don't want to seem like I'm doctor shopping but what I heard today confused me.  Log in to post a reply
